pt: {sc}free{/sc} {sc}release{/sc} {sc}liberate{/sc} {sc}emancipate{/sc} {sc}manumit{/sc} mean to set loose from restraint or constraint. {sc}free{/sc} implies a usually permanent removal from whatever binds, confines, entangles, or oppresses.
{sc}release{/sc} suggests a setting loose from confinement, restraint, or a state of pressure or tension, often without implication of permanent liberation.

pt.t: {it}released{/it} his anger on a punching bag

pt: {sc}liberate{/sc} stresses particularly the resulting state of liberty.
{sc}emancipate{/sc} implies the liberation of a person from subjection or domination.

pt.t: labor-saving devices {it}emancipated{/it} us from household drudgery

et: Middle English {it}manumitten{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}manumettre{/it}, from Latin {it}manumittere{/it}, from {it}manus{/it} hand + {it}mittere{/it} to let go, send
